title: The Subject of Murder: Criminality, Identity, Gender in Nineteenth-Century France
abstractText: The project is an investigation on the ways in which the figure of the murderer was constructed in the French nineteenth century within two disciplinary frameworks; the burgeoning sciences of criminology and alienism (psychiatry) on the one hand, and the aesthetic philosophies of Romanticism and Decadence on the other. The extent to which these models co-exist and inter-penetrate within the cultural imaginary of the century is explored via an analysis of representations and self-representations of the murdering subject in a selection of nineteenth-century writing, (literature, popular, fiction, the criminal memoir, the medical case study).
